cards.question: What is the structure of a Helm chart and what files does it typically include?
cards.answer_textbook: A Helm chart has a defined structure including: Chart.yaml (chart metadata), values.yaml (default values), templates/ (Kubernetes manifests), charts/ (dependencies), and README or NOTES files.
cards.answer_metaphor: Think of the pimp’s hotel ledger — Chart.yaml is his main roster list, values.yaml is his ground rules, templates are the rooms, and charts/ are side hustles he calls in when needed.
cards.answer_realworld: Charts organize Kubernetes manifests so you can reuse, share, and customize application deployments cleanly.

cards.question: How do I install Helm, then add and update repositories?
cards.answer_textbook: Install Helm, then run: `helm version`, `helm repo add <name> <url>`, `helm repo update`.
cards.answer_metaphor: It’s like a pimp adding new blocks of hoes under his control. He checks his own status (helm version), then adds new territories (repos), and updates his roster (repo update).
cards.answer_realworld: You install Helm locally, then point it to chart repositories so you can pull and deploy apps quickly.

cards.question: How can I install a chart like Redis with Helm?
cards.answer_textbook: Run: `helm install my-redis bitnami/redis`. Use `helm list` to see releases, and `helm uninstall my-redis` to remove it.
cards.answer_metaphor: Like a pimp booking a hoe into a hotel room (install), checking the lineup of who’s working (list), and kicking one out when business is done (uninstall).
cards.answer_realworld: You use `helm install` to deploy charts, `helm list` to see what’s running, and `helm uninstall` to clean them up.

cards.question: How do I create a Helm chart and deploy it to my cluster?
cards.answer_textbook: Run: `helm create mychart`, then `helm install myapp ./mychart -f values.yaml`.
cards.answer_metaphor: That’s like a pimp setting up his own custom hotel suite (create chart) and then moving in hoes with custom rules (install using values.yaml).
cards.answer_realworld: You can scaffold a chart with `helm create`, edit it, then install it into Kubernetes with your configuration values.

cards.question: How can I override Helm chart defaults using values.yaml or CLI flags?
cards.answer_textbook: You can set overrides by editing values.yaml or passing flags with `--set key=value` during install/upgrade.
cards.answer_metaphor: It’s like the pimp changing the hotel rules for one specific hoe — either updating the rulebook (values.yaml) or whispering last-minute orders (CLI flags).
cards.answer_realworld: Overrides let you customize each Helm release without modifying the original chart.

cards.question: How do you upgrade a Helm release?
cards.answer_textbook: Use `helm upgrade <release> <chart>` to upgrade to a new version or apply new values.
cards.answer_metaphor: Like a pimp upgrading a hoe’s wardrobe or changing the hotel suite — keeping the same worker but refreshing her setup.
cards.answer_realworld: `helm upgrade` updates an existing release with new config or chart versions without reinstalling from scratch.

cards.question: How do you roll back a Helm release to a previous version?
cards.answer_metaphor: When the pimp realizes the new outfit isn’t working, he rolls her back to a previous look that pulled more clients.
cards.answer_realworld: Rollback lets you revert to a stable version if an upgrade introduces problems.

cards.question: What does `helm template` do?
cards.answer_textbook: It renders Kubernetes manifests locally without installing them.
cards.answer_metaphor: Like the pimp sketching out a floor plan of rooms and hoes before actually opening the hotel for business.
cards.answer_realworld: Useful for debugging and previewing manifests before deploying.

cards.question: What does `helm lint` do?
cards.answer_textbook: Validates a chart for issues in its structure or templates.
cards.answer_metaphor: Like the pimp doing a dress check before sending hoes out on the street.
cards.answer_realworld: Ensures charts follow best practices and contain no errors before installation.

cards.question: What is the order of precedence for Helm values?
cards.answer_textbook: CLI `--set` > values file passed with `-f` > chart’s default values.yaml.
cards.answer_metaphor: A pimp’s whispered orders (CLI flags) override the hotel rulebook (values.yaml), which override the default house rules.
cards.answer_realworld: Lets you layer configurations flexibly depending on context.
